comment.author: 41894168711@N01
comment._content: By taking the time to share these photos you have made these wonderful people immortal!

comment.author: 27814716@N06
comment._content: seeing the backdrops is really interesting and very useful for teaching..particuarly as there are other photos closer up on the figures showing the backdrop effect. e.g. www.flickr.com/photos/australian-war-memorial/2963393284/...

comment.author: 30115723@N02
comment._content: Glad you found this interesting. I was pretty excited when I saw this image because usually each of these studio shots has only one backdrop visible. It gave me a better understanding on the set-up that the Darge Photographic Company had at the camp.

comment.author: 27814716@N06
comment._content: Thanks AWMC. If you have been looking athe Drage Photo Company are you able to say what the two little bits of "apparatus" are? I've put a question on them as a note - one on the floor looks like a reference number and one on the bench - empty packet ?.

comment.author: 30829497@N05
comment._content: I should have known but did not know the AIF were volunteers, but then I went to school in England ; >

comment.author: 30115723@N02
comment._content:
Dear Shapesoftime,
the number on the left on the ground is the negative number and photographer's reference number. All items in this collecction are listed by their numbers. Leters precede them depending on which location they were shot, thoise taken at Seymour Army camp has DASEY in front of the number, DACS were taken at the city studio in Collins Street in Melbourne.
The little box is a bit of a mystery, it has no marking apart from the narrow strip down the side (a striker? for matches although it is very large)

comment.author: 27814716@N06
comment._content:
Dear AWMCol  
Thank you very much for replying...  and answering about the numbers.. all helps to build the picture of how the photographer operated ... and as usual what we see in the digital wolrd (ref numbers, etc embedded in images) isn't so new...  

The box looks like it has a piece cut out down the side - the sort of thing that would let you see how many of whatever was in it were left. Can't be film or flash bulbs or even 'Tic-Tacs-of-the-day'? But it is sitting so carefully, placed it seems after the sitters sat, it is as though it was something to do with the action ... ...  perhaps it's good that the past carries some secrets with it....

comment.author: 27814716@N06
comment._content: Hi JMS - If you enlarge the image up to its original size - click on the magnifying glass - you can see the toe of his other boot in the shadow.  It's just the way he's sitting.
